title: What are the most terrifying sinkhole pictures you've ever seen? - Quora

response.answer_text: The biggest city sinkholes around the world Below are the worlds most terrifying sinkhole pictures I have seen.  The rains of tropical storm Agatha, alongside a volcanic eruption and leakage from sewer pipes created a giant sinkhole in the Guatemalan capital in May 2010 ________________  Berezniki, 2007. This Russian city, home to a number of potassium, magnesium and potash mines, suffers from a number of sinkholes and has to be constantly monitored. This sinkhole is currently over 200m deep, 80m long and 40m wide – and growing_________________ San Francisco, 1995. A sinkhole swallowed two homes and forced the evacuation of nine other homes in San Francisco’s Sea Cliff district in December 1995. The hole measured approximately 200ft by 150ft and was apparently caused by a broken sewer pipe  Guangzhou, 2013. Workers use machinery to fill in a sinkhole that buildings collapsed into near a subway construction site in the Chinese city of Guangzhou. The hole measured about 1,000 sq ft across and was around 30 ft deep  Fukuoka, 2016. A huge sinkhole is seen at an intersection near Hakata station in the Japanese city on November 8, 2016______________ San Francisco, 1998. A car sits in a huge sinkhole on John Muir Drive in San Francisco, after stopped up sewers caused flooding_______________ Guatemala City, 2007. A sinkhole opened up in a residential neighbourhood of the Guatemalan capital. About a dozen homes were swallowed, and three people died.______________ Milwaukee, 2010. A car sits at the bottom of a sinkhole caused by flooding triggered by powerful storms in southeastern Wisconsin_____________ Daisetta, 2008. A large sinkhole swallowed up oil field equipment and vehicles in this southeastern Texan city_______________ Mount Gambier, Australia. Mount Gambier is known for its volcanic craters, caves and sinkholes – and is sometimes referred to as the ‘city of craters’. Victorian terraced gardens were created in the Umpherston limestone sinkhole in 1886.
